item.title: Last year Colorado voted down another unnecessary abortion ban....
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Last year Colorado voted down another unnecessary abortion ban. This year, we need to say no more bans. Our #RJResolution is to ensure affordable access to the healthcare people need, including abortion, and make sure people can become parents when they are ready. #StopTheBans
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Several medical authorities outside and inside Colorado released...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Several medical authorities outside and inside Colorado released guidance on who should have vaccine priority. Against these recommendations, Gov. Polis decided to change Colorado's distribution plan and demoted groups like people experiencing homelessness and those living in congregate settings like jails and prisons.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/…/…/02/covid-vaccine-prisons/

A shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.

washingtonpost.com

Early vaccination in prisons, a public health priority, proves politically charged

A shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.A shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.

item.title: Protecting incarcerated people from COVID-19 is a matter of...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Protecting incarcerated people from COVID-19 is a matter of science, law, and basic humanity.

If officials fail to prioritize incarcerated individuals for the vaccine, we will take them to court.

aclu.org

Incarcerated People Should Get Priority Access to the COVID-19 Vaccine. It's the Smart and Human Thing to Do.

If officials fail to prioritize incarcerated individuals for the vaccine, we will take them to court.If officials fail to prioritize incarcerated individuals for the vaccine, we will take them to court.

item.title: This afternoon, Governor Jared Polis announced that he is...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

This afternoon, Governor Jared Polis announced that he is exercising his clemency power to release four people from prison who deserve a second chance. We know these releases mean a great deal to these four families, and we are celebrating with them. In granting clemency as he has done, Governor Polis leads Colorado in a small step toward redemption and compassion.

We note that many of the petitions the Governor acted on today have been on his desk for months awaiting action.... This includes the petition of Mr. Anthony Martinez, an 84-year old grandfather who suffers from dementia, renal failure and relies on a wheelchair to get around. Mr. Martinez is not a public safety risk and should have been granted clemency long ago. There are also hundreds like Mr. Martinez who can be safely released from our prisons but are left behind in the Governor’s action.

COVID-19 is spreading unabated in Colorado prisons. More than 6,800 people have tested positive for the disease, over 40% of the population has been infected, and a new death is announced every few days. Other Governors are meeting this moment by releasing thousands and yet our Governor releases four, a far cry from what is needed and a far cry from those deserving the mercy and compassion of which the Governor speaks. There are simply way too many people left behind.

Our incarceration system is massive, brutal and suffers greatly from racial inequities. Clemency is the only real corrective check on this unjust system and can only be exercised by the Governor. But for clemency to be an effective check it must be constantly and consistently applied. Once a year during the holidays is not enough. Four people are too few. We urge the Governor to use this corrective power more frequently and to take seriously every petition that lands on his desk in a timely fashion. You, Governor, have the power to define what redemption, mercy and compassion look like. Be bold and do the right thing. Redemption is real, and so is compassion.

This statement can be attributed to Denise Maes, ACLU of Colorado Public Policy Director.

Read the full statement at: https://aclu-co.org/governor-use-of-clemency/

See More
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: "Amber Johnson is terrified her 63-year-old father will get...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

"Amber Johnson is terrified her 63-year-old father will get the coronavirus. He has high blood pressure, asthma and is pre-diabetic, and she worries he’s especially vulnerable as an inmate in Colorado, where outbreaks in prisons are raging."

We won’t get COVID-19 under control in this country until we do so in prisons and jails.

DENVER (AP) — Amber Johnson is terrified her 63-year-old father will get the coronavirus. He has high blood pressure, asthma and is pre-diabetic, and she worries he's especially vulnerable as an...

Inmates facing big virus risks not near top of vaccine lists

item.title: Thank you to the more than 500 people who joined us to watch the...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Thank you to the more than 500 people who joined us to watch the premiere of "The Facility" on Friday. If you missed last week's screening or want to learn more about the film, visit the documentary's website: https://www.thefacilitymovie.com
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.title: Colorado prisons are in crisis. As COVID-19 spreads unabated,...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Colorado prisons are in crisis. As COVID-19 spreads unabated, 6,200 people in prison tested positive for the virus, 17 have died, and hundreds of guards are placed on leave. This staff shortage leaves incarcerated people being fed substandard meals, they go days without showering and sometimes weeks without stepping outside.

The Governor can, and must, take action. We will not forget about incarcerated people during this pandemic. We won’t stop fighting for their right to health and safety.

Some inmates go weeks without stepping outside. Sick prisoners are trading coveted stockpiled foods for Tylenol to relieve their symptoms, families said.

denverpost.com

Staff shortages, extended lockdowns in coronavirus-ridden Colorado prisons create “tenuous” situations

Some inmates go weeks without stepping outside. Sick prisoners are trading coveted stockpiled foods for Tylenol to relieve their symptoms, families said.Some inmates go weeks without stepping outside. Sick prisoners are trading coveted stockpiled foods for Tylenol to relieve their symptoms, families said.
item.author: ACLU of Colorado

item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

“We, I think, all need to look deep into ourselves and ask ourselves why we let a system like this continue to function and continue to thrive, and why it’s received so little attention in the past,” Flood said.

Formerly detained people and their family members share their experiences in an upcoming documentary, titled The Facility.

coloradonewsline.com

Stories of immigrants detained in Aurora told in 'The Facility' - Colorado Newsline

item.title: Tuesday Olson knew her pregnancy was in trouble and tried to...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

Tuesday Olson knew her pregnancy was in trouble and tried to access hospital care as soon as possible. But there was a problem: she was in jail. Thousands of people arrive to jails pregnant each year. At a minimum, they deserve access to medical attention. Learn more about Tuesday's story at: https://aclu-co.org/repro-stories/

Every pregnancy is different, but there are tell-tale signs that something may not be right. Pregnant people know that cramping, bleeding, and intense abdominal pain may be a cause for concern. When Tuesday Olson started experiencing these symptoms, she knew … Continue reading →

aclu-co.org

Repro Stories | ACLU of Colorado

Every pregnancy is different, but there are tell-tale signs that something may not be right. Pregnant people know that cramping, bleeding, and intense abdominal pain may be a cause for concern. item.title: The number of women inside America’s jails is up more than 20%...
item.content:encoded:
ACLU of Colorado

The number of women inside America’s jails is up more than 20% this past decade. That's about more than 115,000 incarcerated women a day. Many arrive in need of medical attention, some with serious health conditions without access to proper care. Thousands who are jailed each year are pregnant.

As the number of women in U.S. jails has risen, so have deaths and medical errors in facilities ill-equipped to handle this growing population.

reuters.com

As more women fill America’s jails, medical tragedies mount

As the number of women in U.S. jails has risen, so have deaths and medical errors in facilities ill-equipped to handle this growing population.As the number of women in U.S. jails has risen, so have deaths and medical errors in facilities ill-equipped to handle this growing population.
